rewrite.title: Satellite Images Expose Heat Waste at Major Crypto Mine
rewrite.body:
A pioneering satellite image has unveiled the substantial heat leakage from one of the largest Bitcoin mining operations in the United States, located in Rockdale, Texas. This facility, managed by Riot Platforms, draws approximately 700 megawatts of power—comparable to the electricity consumption of 300,000 households—highlighting the immense energy demands of cryptocurrency mining. The thermal image, captured by SatVu’s HotSat-1 satellite with an unprecedented resolution of 11.5 feet, distinctly maps heat emissions from critical infrastructure such as rooftop chillers, transformers, and electrical yards, providing a real-time snapshot of the facility’s operational intensity.

This breakthrough in thermal imaging offers regulators and grid operators a powerful tool to objectively monitor the environmental footprint and energy consumption of rapidly expanding data centers. Unlike traditional reporting, which often lags behind actual operations, SatVu’s thermal data delivers immediate, evidence-based insights into how these centers impact local power grids and the environment. Given that global investments in data centers are expected to surpass $7 billion by 2030 and that data centers contribute about 0.5% of global carbon emissions, such monitoring is increasingly critical.

Bitcoin mining, in particular, is noted for its high carbon intensity; recent studies estimate that a single Bitcoin transaction produces carbon emissions comparable to driving a gasoline car for 1,600 miles. SatVu’s ongoing satellite program, with HotSat-2 and HotSat-3 launches planned, aims to expand this thermal surveillance, potentially transforming how industrial energy use and environmental impacts are tracked from space. This technological advancement could play a key role in balancing the growth of digital infrastructure with sustainability goals.
